awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Consequences of Co-Adsorbed Chlorine on Surface Dynamics and Selectivity in Ethylene Epoxidation on Silver Catalysts
awd_abstract_narration:
Ethylene oxide (EO) is a major commodity chemical used in the production of materials, industrial solutions, surfactants and consumer goods.  EO is manufactured via a catalytic reaction between ethylene and oxygen gas utilizing highly complex catalysts that have evolved over the years primarily through industrial research involving experimental screening of a large array of catalytic, promoter, and stabilizing materials.  While those efforts have led to high-performing catalysts containing five or more promoting materials, there remains significant opportunity to improve the catalyst technology.  State-of-the art theory, machine learning, spectroscopic and reaction analysis methods will be combined to better understand the role of chlorine, one of the key promoting elements, and identify opportunities for increasing its effectiveness.  Higher-performing EO catalysts would improve process energy efficiency, reduce emissions, and promote U.S. competitiveness in a chemical market sector that accounted for $45B in 2016.
 
Among the many different combinations of promoters reported in commercial EO catalysts, chlorine (Cl) is the most ubiquitous promoter, and its addition to an otherwise unmodified silver (Ag) catalyst leads to the greatest increase in selectivity to EO. Reactant and promoter-induced surface dynamics and reconstruction have long been known to play a critical role in many catalytic reactions. The study combines catalyst synthesis, spectroscopic characterization, reactivity testing, and machine-learning enhanced molecular simulations, to explore the dynamic nature of the Cl-promoted Ag surface under reaction conditions. The bottom-up approach to synthesis and characterization yields itself to several opportunities for reconciling conflicting spectroscopic assignments in the literature, mechanistic proposals for this system, and hypotheses for the mode of action of Cl through the combination of cutting-edge computational and experimental methods.  Specifically, the study will utilize efficient computational approaches for modeling dynamic evolution of systems with high configurational complexity. Time-averaged simulated Raman spectra derived from molecular dynamics simulations will be used in conjunction with multi-variate curve resolution of experimental Raman spectra to make molecularly precise assignments for different surface oxygen species and the influence of Cl on their structure. The transient behavior of these systems will also be tied to observations at steady-state operation at conditions relevant for industrial systems.  The collaborative nature of the project will provide opportunities for cross-exposure of graduate students from the two research groups to theoretical and experimental methods, thereby teaching skills for effective research collaboration. The methodologies developed in the research and their application will be integrated into graduate courses taught by the co-investigators to demonstrate the importance of embracing complexity of catalytic systems, even within fundamental studies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Ethylene oxide (EO) is a key intermediate in the chemical industry, with worldwide production of EO exceeding 27 billion kilograms. The primary source of EO is the reaction of ethylene and oxygen over silver (Ag) catalysts. The Ag catalysts are promoted with complex combinations of five or more elements, each with different roles in catalysis. This project employed a bottom-up technical strategy of starting from unsupported Ag nanoparticles in mixtures of ethylene and oxygen, and subsequently increasing complexity. The project explored the surface structures and reactive oxygen species for active Ag. The EO selectivity of current industrial process technology is above 90%, however, opportunities exist to further increase the selectivity while simultaneously improving process efficiency and decreasing CO2 emissions.

 

This project combined advanced experimental, computational, and machine learning methods to better understand the catalytic mechanism of EO manufacture and the role played by different surface and subsurface oxygen species and the Cl promoter. Surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) and density functional theory (DFT) calculations led to the identification of different reactive oxygen species (e.g. atomic and diatomic oxygen) on the Ag surface. Development of principle component analysis methods for SERS data and DFT-computed Raman intensities enabled the quantification of how the populations of different oxygen species evolve during exposure to varying ratios of ethylene and oxygen reactants, and transient reduction (by dihydrogen) and oxidation experiments. These observations lead to the realization that even in the absence of Cl promoter the nature of the Ag surface under reaction conditions is complex and contains multiple types of surface and subsurface oxygen species. These oxygen species are not all accurately described by previously reported molecular models. To model Ag-O and Ag-O-Cl interactions on surfaces large enough to capture these complexities, machine learning-based molecular simulation methods were developed during the project. In preliminary results, these models combined with spectroscopic experiments enable the determination of how different oxygen species react with ethylene and influence the selectivity to EO.

 

This project had broader impacts in both the scientific community and education of students. The simulation and spectroscopic tools developed during the project can be used to capture the complexity and dynamics of other metal catalysts used for oxidative reactions. These methods enable molecular understanding of evolving catalyst surface structures with a higher level of complexity than previously understood. The project involved training of 3 graduate students, which included communication of their work internally and at both regional and national conferences. Results obtained from this project were also communicated as examples of the complexity of catalyst surfaces during reactions with even comparatively simple reactants.
